elements.content: The reaction of (n-Bu3Sn)2O with pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (L1H 2 ) in a 1:1 ratio resulted in the formation of a one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer [(n-Bu3Sn)2(n-Bu2Sn)2(μ-L1)2(μ-OH)2] n (1). The formation of 1 is accompanied by a Sn–butyl bond cleavage reaction involving half of the organotin units. The formation of the 1D coordination polymer is facilitated by the multisite coordination capability of the dianionic ligand L1. The reaction of (n-Bu3Sn)2O with pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (L2H 2 ) or pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (L3H 2 ), on the other hand, results in the generation of the two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymers [(n-Bu3Sn)2(μ-L2)] n (2) and [(n-Bu3Sn)4(μ-L3)2] n (3), respectively. The formation of 2 and 3 emphasizes the importance of the relative orientation of the coordinating units in the multisite coordination ligand. Compounds 1–3 show a rich supramolecular architecture in their solid state as a result of multiple secondary interactions. Investigation of the fate of the reactions of (n-Bu3Sn)2O with pyridine dicarboxylic acids in the presence of a bridging ligand was carried out. In all the cases when the reactions were carried out in the presence of 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bipy), 1D coordination polymers [(n-Bu3Sn)2(μ-L1)(μ-4,4′-bipy)] n (4), [(n-Bu3Sn)2(μ-L3)(μ-4,4′-bipy)] n (5), and [(n-Bu3Sn)2(μ-L2)(μ-4,4′-bipy)] n (6) are formed. In these cases, the 4,4′-bipyridine ligand serves as one of the connectors that link the organotin units. Interestingly, in the presence of 4,4′-bipyridine, Sn–butyl bond cleavage does not take place. While the 1D coordination polymers 4 and 5 form three-dimensional supramolecular architectures in their solid state, compound 6 possesses a 2D supramolecular architecture.

elements.content: The reactions of organotin oxides, -hydroxides, and oxide-hydroxides with protic acids (carboxylic acids, sulfonic acids, phosphinic acids, and phosphonic acids) have been a subject of intense study. This interest has been due to the enormous structural diversity present in this family of compounds. A second reason for this interest is because well-defined organostannoxane scaffolds can be used to support functional peripheries. However, in spite of considerable work in this area, there have been relatively few reports on the reactions of organotin substrates with dicarboxylic acids. In recent years, the utility of dicarboxylic acids in forming novel coordination assemblies in general, and metal–organic frame works in particular, has been extremely well documented. Such studies are surprisingly quite limited with respect to main-group metal-containing assemblies. In view of this importance, it was of interest to examine the reactions of organotin compounds with selected dicarboxylic acids. Recent work from some research groups and ours already has shown the exciting possibilities that exist in this area. Thus, for example, Höpfl and co-workers were able to isolate novel macrocylces and coordination polymers in the reactions of diorganotin compounds with aromatic dicarboxylic acids. A representative example is shown in Chart . From our research group we have explored the reactions of pyrazole-dicarboxylic acids and have shown the formation of novel macrocycles as well as coordination polymers (Chart ). However, in most of these studies apart from the dicarboxylic acids the organotin substrate also is potentially difunctional. In order to obtain a better understanding of the reactivity and structural preferences of the products, we have felt that it would be important to study the reactions of triorganotin compounds with dicarboxylic acids. Such a study will allow a more systematic understanding of these reactions. Accordingly, we have investigated the reactions of (n-Bu3Sn)2O with pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (L1H 2 ), pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (L2H 2 ), and pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (L3H 2 ), and the products obtained viz., [(n-Bu3Sn)2(n-Bu2Sn)2(μ-L1)2(μ–OH)2] n (1), [(n-Bu3Sn)2(μ-L2)] n (2), and [(n-Bu3Sn)4(μ-L3)2] n (3), were characterized as coordination polymers. During our studies on molecular transition metal phosphonates, we have discovered that ancillary nitrogen ligands play an important role in the final product formation. We wanted to test this idea in the current instance also, and accordingly we carried out the reactions of (n-Bu3Sn)2O with pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (L1H 2 ), pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (L2H 2 ), and pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (L3H 2 ) in the presence of 4,4′-bipyridine. A new set of one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymers, [(n-Bu3Sn)2(μ-L1)(μ-4,4′-bipy)] n (4), [(n-Bu3Sn)2(μ-L3)(μ-4,4′-bipy)] n (5), and [(n-Bu3Sn)2(μ-L2)(μ-4,4′-bipy)] n (6), were isolated. Herein, we describe the synthesis and structural characterization of the new organotin-based coordination polymers 1–6.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The reactions of organotin oxides, -hydroxides, and oxide-hydroxides with protic acids (carboxylic acids, sulfonic acids, phosphinic acids, and phosphonic acids) have been a subject of intense study. This interest has been due to the enormous structural diversity present in this family of compounds. A second reason for this interest is because well-defined organostannoxane scaffolds can be used to support functional peripheries. However, in spite of considerable work in this area, there have been relatively few reports on the reactions of organotin substrates with dicarboxylic acids. In recent years, the utility of dicarboxylic acids in forming novel coordination assemblies in general, and metal-organic frame works in particular, has been extremely well documented. Such studies are surprisingly quite limited with respect to main-group metal-containing assemblies. In view of this importance, it was of interest to examine the reactions of organotin compounds with selected dicarboxylic acids. Recent work from some research groups and ours already has shown the exciting possibilities that exist in this area. Thus, for example, Höpfl and co-workers were able to isolate novel macrocylces and coordination polymers in the reactions of diorganotin compounds with aromatic dicarboxylic acids. A representative example is shown in Chart . From our research group we have explored the reactions of pyrazole-dicarboxylic acids and have shown the formation of novel macrocycles as well as coordination polymers (Chart ). However, in most of these studies apart from the dicarboxylic acids the organotin substrate also is potentially difunctional. In order to obtain a better understanding of the reactivity and structural preferences of the products, we have felt that it would be important to study the reactions of triorganotin compounds with dicarboxylic acids. Such a study will allow a more systematic understanding of these reactions. Accordingly, we have investigated the reactions of (n-Bu3Sn)2O with pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (L1H  2 ), pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (L2H  2 ), and pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (L3H  2 ), and the products obtained viz., [(n-Bu3Sn)2(n-Bu2Sn)2(μ-L1)2(μ-OH)2] n  (1), [(n-Bu3Sn)2(μ-L2)] n  (2), and [(n-Bu3Sn)4(μ-L3)2] n  (3), were characterized as coordination polymers. During our studies on molecular transition metal phosphonates, we have discovered that ancillary nitrogen ligands play an important role in the final product formation. We wanted to test this idea in the current instance also, and accordingly we carried out the reactions of (n-Bu3Sn)2O with pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (L1H  2 ), pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (L2H  2 ), and pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (L3H  2 ) in the presence of 4,4'-bipyridine. A new set of one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymers, [(n-Bu3Sn)2(μ-L1)(μ-4,4'-bipy)] n  (4), [(n-Bu3Sn)2(μ-L3)(μ-4,4'-bipy)] n  (5), and [(n-Bu3Sn)2(μ-L2)(μ-4,4'-bipy)] n  (6), were isolated. Herein, we describe the synthesis and structural characterization of the new organotin-based coordination polymers 1-6.

elements.content: The reactions of (n-Bu3Sn)2O with the pyridine-dicarboxylic acids L1H2, L2H2, and L3H2 proceed smoothly affording compounds 1–3 in good yields (Scheme ; for synthetic details see ). The formation of 1 is accompanied by a rare Sn–butyl bond cleavage reaction. While Sn–C bond cleavage is quite facile particularly in compounds possessing Sn-allyl and Sn-benzyl motifs, such reactions have been rarely reported in other situations. From our laboratory, we have earlier reported instances of Sn–Ph bond cleavage reaction in the formation of [Ph2Sn(OH)OC(O)(Rf)]2 and a Sn–Bu bond cleavage reaction in the formation {[n-Bu2Sn(H2O)3(L)Sn-(H2O)3 n-Bu2]2+[L]2–}·2MeOH·2H2O The X-ray crystal structures of 1–3 (vide infra) reveal that these compounds possess extended structures and are 1D or two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

The reactions of (n-Bu3Sn)2O with the pyridine-dicarboxylic acids L1H2, L2H2, and L3H2 proceed smoothly affording compounds 1-3 in good yields (Scheme ; for synthetic details see ). The formation of 1 is accompanied by a rare Sn-butyl bond cleavage reaction. While Sn-C bond cleavage is quite facile particularly in compounds possessing Sn-allyl and Sn-benzyl motifs, such reactions have been rarely reported in other situations. From our laboratory, we have earlier reported instances of Sn-Ph bond cleavage reaction in the formation of [Ph2Sn(OH)OC(O)(Rf)]2  and a Sn-Bu bond cleavage reaction in the formation {[n-Bu2Sn(H2O)3(L)Sn-(H2O)3 n-Bu2]2+[L]2-}⋅2MeOH⋅2H2O The X-ray crystal structures of 1-3 (vide infra) reveal that these compounds possess extended structures and are 1D or two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymers.

elements.content:
The reactions of (n-Bu3Sn)2O with the pyridine-dicarboxylic acids L1H2, L2H2, and L3H2 in the presence of 4,4′-bipyridine afforded 1D-coordination polymers 4–6 (Scheme ; see for synthetic details).

Compounds 1–6 do not seem to retain their structural integrity in solution as evidenced by electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) (see and ). The X-ray crystal structures of 1–6 are discussed in the following section.
elements.clean_text:
The reactions of (n-Bu3Sn)2O with the pyridine-dicarboxylic acids L1H2, L2H2, and L3H2 in the presence of 4,4'-bipyridine afforded 1D-coordination polymers 4-6 (Scheme ; see  for synthetic details).

Compounds 1-6 do not seem to retain their structural integrity in solution as evidenced by electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) (see  and ). The X-ray crystal structures of 1-6 are discussed in the following section.

elements.content:
The crystal data of compounds 1–6 are summarized in Tables and . The coordination modes of the pyridine dicarboxylate ligands in these compounds is summarized in Chart .

Harris notation is used as per ref .

X-ray Crystal Structure of <bold>1</bold>

The solid-state structure of 1, which is a 1D-coordination polymer, is depicted in Figure a. The formation of 1 is accompanied by a Sn–C bond cleavage reaction. While Sn–C bond cleavage reactions are known, particularly for compounds containing Sn-benzyl or Sn-allyl substituents, they are uncommon with other Sn-R groups, although in recent years, from our laboratory we have reported instances of Sn–C cleavage from compounds containing Sn-butyl and Sn-aryl substituents.

X-ray Crystal Structure of 1 

The solid-state structure of 1, which is a 1D-coordination polymer, is depicted in Figure a. The formation of 1 is accompanied by a Sn-C bond cleavage reaction. While Sn-C bond cleavage reactions are known, particularly for compounds containing Sn-benzyl or Sn-allyl substituents, they are uncommon with other Sn-R groups, although in recent years, from our laboratory we have reported instances of Sn-C cleavage from compounds containing Sn-butyl and Sn-aryl substituents.

elements.content: The coordination polymer 1 consists of two tightly connected diorganotin centers. The dianionic pyridine dicarboxylate ligand binds to each of these two tin centers in a pincer-like manner utilizing the pyridine nitrogen atom and the adjacent carboxylates generating two five-membered rings around each tin center (Chart ; Figure ).

The dianionic pyridine dicarboxylate ligand binds to each of these two tin centers in a pincer-like manner utilizing the pyridine nitrogen atom and the adjacent carboxylates generating two five-membered rings around each tin center (Chart ; Figure ).

elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Coordination of the Pyridine Carboxylate Ligand Generating the Ditin Motif and (b) the Two Five-Membered Rings around the Two Tin Centers in the Ditin Motif

elements.content: The residual coordination action of one of the carboxylate oxygen atoms on each tin helps to establish connectivity between the two tins with the formation of a four-membered Sn2O2 ring; as a result, five contiguous tin-containing rings are put in place (Scheme ). Two such ditin motifs are connected to each other by intervening bridging units which include two triorganotin motifs. Each triorganotin unit is linked to the diorganotin part of the ditin motif by a bridging hydroxide ligand on side and by the residual coordination action of the carboxylate ligand on the other. This leads to the formation of a 12-membered macrocycle (Sn4C2O6). Interestingly, the macrocycle is completely planar (Figure b) with the deviations of the various atoms from the mean plane being quite low (). The coordination polymer 1 consists of two types of tin atoms. The diorganotin centers (Sn2 and Sn2′) are seven-coordinate (4O, 2C, N) (Chart a). The coordination geometry around Sn2 and Sn2′ is pentagonal bipyramidal (Figure c) where the two carbon atoms occupy the apical positions. The coordination environment around the triorganotin units (Sn1 and Sn1′) comprises of three carbon atoms and two oxygen atoms in a trigonal bipyramidal geometry (Figure c). The bond distances around the tin atoms follow trends known in the literature. Thus, the diorganotin Sn2 is bound by two chelating units. One of the oxygen atoms involved is also present in a four-membered ring. This distance Sn2–O3 is 2.427(3) Å and is longer than its counterpart, Sn2–O2 [2.207(3) Å]; O2 is not involved in residual coordination. On the other hand the Sn2–O3′ distance is 2.823(3) Å. The tin–nitrogen distance Sn2–N1 is 2.484(4) Å. The Sn2–O–Sn2′ bond angle is 116.31(14)° and the O3–Sn–O3′ bond angle is 63.68(11)°. The Sn–O bond distance around the tin atom present in the trigonal bipyramidal geometry, Sn1–O5, is 2.163 (4) Å, while the other distance involving Sn1–O1 is 2.485 (3) Å. The O–Sn1–O bond angle is nearly linear and is 177.4(1)°. The salient metric parameters of 1 are summarized in Table .

The supramolecular structure of 1 involves weak C–H---π interactions between the n-butyl groups attached to Sn1 atoms of one 1D chain with the aromatic pyridyl group of another [C15–H15C---π(pyridine ring); 3.423(1) Å]. This interaction is complemented by a C–H---O hydrogen bonding interaction between the adjacent chains [C14–H14A---O4; 2.722(4) Å, C14–H14A–O4; 143.30(29)°] (Figure a). Such interactions perpetuate into a 2D supramolecular architecture (Figure b).

This interaction is complemented by a C-H---O hydrogen bonding interaction between the adjacent chains [C14-H14A---O4; 2.722(4) Å, C14-H14A-O4; 143.30(29)°] (Figure a). Such interactions perpetuate into a 2D supramolecular architecture (Figure b).

elements.content: Compound 2 is a planar 2D-polymer containing interconnected 26-membered (Sn4O8C12N2) macrocyclic rings (Figure ). Each macrocyclic ring consists of four triorganotin units and two dicarboxylate ligands. Because of the 2,5-disposition of the carboxylate groups, the pyridine nitrogen atoms are not involved in coordination interactions. Each tin atom is trigonal bipyramidal (3C, 2O) and the tin oxygen distances are Sn1–O2 2.183 (4) Å and Sn1–O1 2.441(5) Å. The average Sn–O bond distance is 2.312(4) Å. The average O–Sn–O bond angle is 170.18(1)° (). The salient metric parameters of 2 are summarized in Table . Surprisingly, in spite of its large size each macrocyclic ring is quite planar (). The 2D-polymer contains a criss-cross arrangement of the macrocyclic rings (Figure ). Within each macrocyclic ring two types of inter-tin distances are found (9.443 and 5.373 Å) (Figure ). The arrangement of the 2D-sheets within the crystal structure is nearly one above the other (). The inter-tin distance between such successive planar sheets is 9.699 Å ().

The 2D-polymer contains a criss-cross arrangement of the macrocyclic rings (Figure ). Within each macrocyclic ring two types of inter-tin distances are found (9.443 and 5.373 Å) (Figure ). elements.content: Compound 3 is also a 2D coordination polymer although its structural architecture is different from that of 2 (Figure ). The salient metric parameters of 3 are summarized in Table . 3 also contains an interconnected network of macrocyclic rings; however, in this case three types of macrocyles are present (rings A, B and C, Figure ). While ring A is 28-membered (Sn4O6C16N2), ring B is 20-membered (Sn4O6C8N2) and ring C is 24-membered (Sn4O6N2C12) (). Interestingly, as in 2, in the present instance also all the macrocyclic rings are nearly planar (). The inter-tin distances within these macrocyclic rings are summarized in Figure . The macrocycles A and B are arranged in one column alternately, while the adjacent column contains a criss-cross arrangement of the macrocycles C. The 4.11101 (Chart ) coordination mode of the pyridine 3,5-dicarboxylate ligand in 3 is given in . Unlike 2, in the present instance, each of the pyridine nitrogen atoms of the dicarboxylate ligands is also involved in binding. As seen in Chart , each ligand binds to four different tin centers. The coordination environments of the two different types of tin atoms are summarized in along with some important metrical parameters. The crystal structure of 3 also contains 2D parallel sheets with an inter-sheet distance of 9.795(5) Å ().

elements.content: The X-ray crystal structure of 4 is shown in Figure a. This compound is a 1D coordination polymer. The salient metric parameters of 4 are summarized in Table . The effect of the 4,4′-bipyridine ring in altering the core structure of 1 can be clearly seen. First, in contrast to 1 where Sn-butyl cleavage occurs, in 4 such a reaction is inhibited. Second, the tightly bound ditin motif present in 1 gives way and the 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate ligand acts a connector and binds two successive tin atoms. The nitrogen atom of the ligand now remains uncoordinated. The 4,4′-bipyridine ligand is also involved in a bridging coordination mode and alternates with the dicarboxylate ligand in forming the polymer chain. The coordination environment of various tin atoms and their bonding parameters are summarized in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystal Structures of 4, 5, and 6 

The X-ray crystal structure of 4 is shown in Figure a. This compound is a 1D coordination polymer. The salient metric parameters of 4 are summarized in Table . The effect of the 4,4'-bipyridine ring in altering the core structure of 1 can be clearly seen. First, in contrast to 1 where Sn-butyl cleavage occurs, in 4 such a reaction is inhibited. Second, the tightly bound ditin motif present in 1 gives way and the 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate ligand acts a connector and binds two successive tin atoms. The nitrogen atom of the ligand now remains uncoordinated. The 4,4'-bipyridine ligand is also involved in a bridging coordination mode and alternates with the dicarboxylate ligand in forming the polymer chain. The coordination environment of various tin atoms and their bonding parameters are summarized in .

elements.content: In its crystal structure, the 1D polymers of 4 interact with each other by C–H---π supramolecular interactions [C5–H5---π (pyridine ring of the pyridine dicarboxylic acid); 2.912(4) Å] (). This interaction leads to the creation of a 3D supramolecular architecture (Figure b).

The X-ray crystal structure of 6 is shown in Figure a. 6 also is a 1D coordination polymer whose structure is similar to that of 4 and 5; however, its supramolecular assembly is different. The salient metric parameters of 6 are summarized in Table . Unlike 4 and 5 the 1D polymers of 6 interact with each other by both C–H---O and C–H---π interactions. There are two different C–H---O hydrogen bonding interactions to O2 from H5 and H7 [C5–H5---O2(2.411(3) Å); C7–H7---O2(2.431(2) Å)] and a C–H---π interaction of H4 with the π electrons of the pyridine ring [C4–H4---π(pyridine ring); (2.863(1) Å)]. Together, these interactions generate a 2D supramolecular structure (Figure b).

Together, these interactions generate a 2D supramolecular structure (Figure b).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out for complexes 1–6, in order to investigate their thermal stability (see Figures S7–S12 of ). The thermogravimetric curve of compound 1 shows that the compound is stable up to ∼160 °C, and then a noticeable weight loss up to 300 °C is seen (nearly 70 wt %). Finally, at 500 °C the char residue is only about 10%. The 2D-coordination polymers 2 and 3 have better thermal stability than 1. Compound 2 has a minimal weight loss up to ∼200 °C, while 3 does not suffer any major weight loss until ∼225 °C. Then both compounds are losing weight up to 300 °C sharply. Char yields for both are ∼10% of starting weight. Compound 4 is stable up to 185 °C, and then it loses about 80% of total weight by 400 °C. Compounds 5 and 6 show similar thermal behavior as that of 4. Both of these are stable up to 160 °C and then losing about 80% of total weight by 300 °C. Thus, all the organostannoxane-based assemblies described herein show a reasonable level of thermal stability.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Properties of Compounds 1-6 

Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out for complexes 1-6, in order to investigate their thermal stability (see Figures S7-S12 of ). The thermogravimetric curve of compound 1 shows that the compound is stable up to ~160 °C, and then a noticeable weight loss up to 300 °C is seen (nearly 70 wt %). Finally, at 500 °C the char residue is only about 10%. The 2D-coordination polymers 2 and 3 have better thermal stability than 1. Compound 2 has a minimal weight loss up to ~200 °C, while 3 does not suffer any major weight loss until ~225 °C. Then both compounds are losing weight up to 300 °C sharply. Char yields for both are ~10% of starting weight. Compound 4 is stable up to 185 °C, and then it loses about 80% of total weight by 400 °C. Compounds 5 and 6 show similar thermal behavior as that of 4. Both of these are stable up to 160 °C and then losing about 80% of total weight by 300 °C. Thus, all the organostannoxane-based assemblies described herein show a reasonable level of thermal stability.

elements.content: Pyridine dicarboxylate ligands provide an effective coordination platform in their reactions with bis(tributyl)tin oxide, to generate 1D- and 2D-coordination polymers. The relative disposition of the two carboxylate ligands vis-à-vis the pyridyl nitrogen atom effectively controls the type of product formed. Pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate, with its ability to form tight chelate rings, drives the reaction affording exclusively the 1D coordination polymer, 1. An unusual aspect of this reaction is that one-half of the organotin centers have undergone an unusual Sn–butyl cleavage reaction. Pyridine-2,5- and pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylate ligands that cannot involve a chelate mode of coordination utilize the full potential of the carboxylate coordination affording 2D networks 2 and 3. In all the cases, if a third component is used in the reaction in the form of the ancillary ligand, 4,4′-bipyridine, 1D coordination polymers 4–6 are obtained. In these reactions the dominant structure-directing role appears to be that of the ancillary ligand which alternates with the pyridine-dicarboxylate ligands in a bridging coordination mode to form chain structures. 3D metal organic frame works containing Lewis acidic tin atoms and Lewis basic pyridine nitrogen atoms are an intriguing possibility that we hope can be realized by applying the principles of this study to multifunctional organotin substrates. We are currently exploring these possibilities.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Pyridine dicarboxylate ligands provide an effective coordination platform in their reactions with bis(tributyl)tin oxide, to generate 1D- and 2D-coordination polymers. The relative disposition of the two carboxylate ligands vis-à-vis the pyridyl nitrogen atom effectively controls the type of product formed. Pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate, with its ability to form tight chelate rings, drives the reaction affording exclusively the 1D coordination polymer, 1. An unusual aspect of this reaction is that one-half of the organotin centers have undergone an unusual Sn-butyl cleavage reaction. Pyridine-2,5- and pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylate ligands that cannot involve a chelate mode of coordination utilize the full potential of the carboxylate coordination affording 2D networks 2 and 3. In all the cases, if a third component is used in the reaction in the form of the ancillary ligand, 4,4'-bipyridine, 1D coordination polymers 4-6 are obtained. In these reactions the dominant structure-directing role appears to be that of the ancillary ligand which alternates with the pyridine-dicarboxylate ligands in a bridging coordination mode to form chain structures. 3D metal organic frame works containing Lewis acidic tin atoms and Lewis basic pyridine nitrogen atoms are an intriguing possibility that we hope can be realized by applying the principles of this study to multifunctional organotin substrates. We are currently exploring these possibilities.

elements.content: Solvents were distilled and dried prior to use according to standard procedures. Pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid, pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid, pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid, 4,4′-bipyridine are from Aldrich. Melting points were measured using a JSGW melting point apparatus and are uncorrected. Elemental analyses were carried out using a Thermoquest CE instruments model EA/110 CHNS-O elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a FT-IR Bruker-Vector model. 1H and 119Sn NMR spectra were obtained on a JEOL-DELTA2 500 model spectrometer using CDCl3 as solvent. Chemical shifts were referenced with respect to tetramethylsilane (for 1H NMR) and tetramethyltin (for 119Sn NMR), respectively. 119Sn NMR spectra were recorded under broad-band decoupled conditions. Thermogravimetric Analysis was carried out on a Perkin-Elmer Pyris 6 Thermogravimetric analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Solvents were distilled and dried prior to use according to standard procedures. Pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid, pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid, pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid, 4,4'-bipyridine are from Aldrich. Melting points were measured using a JSGW melting point apparatus and are uncorrected. Elemental analyses were carried out using a Thermoquest CE instruments model EA/110 CHNS-O elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a FT-IR Bruker-Vector model. 1H and 119Sn NMR spectra were obtained on a JEOL-DELTA2 500 model spectrometer using CDCl3 as solvent. Chemical shifts were referenced with respect to tetramethylsilane (for 1H NMR) and tetramethyltin (for 119Sn NMR), respectively. 119Sn NMR spectra were recorded under broad-band decoupled conditions. Thermogravimetric Analysis was carried out on a Perkin-Elmer Pyris 6 Thermogravimetric analyzer.

elements.content: A mixture of (n-Bu3Sn)2O and pyridine dicarboxylic acid (1:1 stoichiometric ratio) was heated under reflux in a mixture of toluene and methanol (50 mL, v/v, 3:2) for 9 h affording a clear solution. The reaction mixture was filtered and the solvent was removed in vacuo to afford a white powder as the product.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

General Synthetic Procedure

Compounds 1-3 

A mixture of (n-Bu3Sn)2O and pyridine dicarboxylic acid (1:1 stoichiometric ratio) was heated under reflux in a mixture of toluene and methanol (50 mL, v/v, 3:2) for 9 h affording a clear solution. The reaction mixture was filtered and the solvent was removed in vacuo to afford a white powder as the product.

elements.content: A mixture of (n-Bu3Sn)2O, pyridine dicarboxylic acid, and 4,4′-bipyridine (1:1:1 stoichiometric ratio) was heated under reflux in 50 mL of toluene for 9 h to get a clear solution. The reaction mixture was filtered and the solvent was removed in vacuo to afford a white powder as the product.
elements.clean_text:
Compounds 4-6 

A mixture of (n-Bu3Sn)2O, pyridine dicarboxylic acid, and 4,4'-bipyridine (1:1:1 stoichiometric ratio) was heated under reflux in 50 mL of toluene for 9 h to get a clear solution. The reaction mixture was filtered and the solvent was removed in vacuo to afford a white powder as the product.

elements.content: The crystal data for compounds 1–6 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD Diffractrometer. SMART software package (version 5.628) was used for collecting data frames, SAINT software package (version 6.45) for integration of the intensity and scaling and SADABS was used for absorption correction. The structures were solved and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 using SHELXTL software package. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. In both cases of compound 2 and compound 6, since the crystallographic symmetry is higher than the symmetry of the compound we have modeled them with 25% N and 75% C in both positions at N1 and C3 and then generated the diagram with unique parts. Figures – and their bonding parameters were obtained from the DIAMOND 3.1f software package.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Study

The crystal data for compounds 1-6 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD Diffractrometer. SMART software package (version 5.628) was used for collecting data frames, SAINT software package (version 6.45) for integration of the intensity and scaling and SADABS was used for absorption correction. The structures were solved and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 using SHELXTL software package. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. In both cases of compound 2 and compound 6, since the crystallographic symmetry is higher than the symmetry of the compound we have modeled them with 25% N and 75% C in both positions at N1 and C3 and then generated the diagram with unique parts. Figures - and their bonding parameters were obtained from the DIAMOND 3.1f software package.

The reaction mixture was filtered and the solvent was removed in vacuo to afford a white powder as the product.

cln_elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out for complexes 1–6, in order to investigate their thermal stability (see Figures S7–S12 of ). The thermogravimetric curve of compound 1 shows that the compound is stable up to ∼160 °C, and then a noticeable weight loss up to 300 °C is seen (nearly 70 wt %). Finally, at 500 °C the char residue is only about 10%. The 2D-coordination polymers 2 and 3 have better thermal stability than 1. Compound 2 has a minimal weight loss up to ∼200 °C, while 3 does not suffer any major weight loss until ∼225 °C. Then both compounds are losing weight up to 300 °C sharply. Char yields for both are ∼10% of starting weight. Compound 4 is stable up to 185 °C, and then it loses about 80% of total weight by 400 °C. Compounds 5 and 6 show similar thermal behavior as that of 4. Both of these are stable up to 160 °C and then losing about 80% of total weight by 300 °C. Thus, all the organostannoxane-based assemblies described herein show a reasonable level of thermal stability.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Properties of Compounds 1-6 

Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out for complexes 1-6, in order to investigate their thermal stability (see Figures S7-S12 of ). The thermogravimetric curve of compound 1 shows that the compound is stable up to ~160 °C, and then a noticeable weight loss up to 300 °C is seen (nearly 70 wt %). Finally, at 500 °C the char residue is only about 10%. The 2D-coordination polymers 2 and 3 have better thermal stability than 1. Compound 2 has a minimal weight loss up to ~200 °C, while 3 does not suffer any major weight loss until ~225 °C. Then both compounds are losing weight up to 300 °C sharply. Char yields for both are ~10% of starting weight. Compound 4 is stable up to 185 °C, and then it loses about 80% of total weight by 400 °C. Compounds 5 and 6 show similar thermal behavior as that of 4. Both of these are stable up to 160 °C and then losing about 80% of total weight by 300 °C. Thus, all the organostannoxane-based assemblies described herein show a reasonable level of thermal stability.
